lexUnit.name: captivate.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: attract and hold the interest and attention of; charm.

sentence.text: The peanut farmer captivated America with his Colgate smile but he was a different sight three years into his presidency when he took part in a six-mile road race .
James Fillis was a riding master of the last century who captivated large audiences with his over-bent horses with unnatural gaits .
The declamatory , repetitive , rhythmic prose of Ossian throbs with urgent sonorities and captivates the ear with its haunting incantations .
She captivated me by her touchingly comic manner ( which the lifeguard also noticed , for the corner of his mouth twitched slightly ) .
Naples , the capital city , once captivated Europe by its artistic patronage and a Victorian ` Grand Tour " was barely conceivable without it .
Charlie Chaplin 's silent black and white movies captivated the world in the early part of the century â€¦ and they 're still doing it for a new generation coming through .
They were always flavoured with her subtle Parmigiano-Jewish humour and could captivate any audience .
The design must captivate the audience .
Diana had captivated the country ; Charles was proud , but Diana was beginning to upstage him
Her innocence and enthusiasm captivated him .
With talk of sweetbreads and liver and fillet she captivated him -- I could n't quite see how she did it .
The posters were signed : ` The Little Green Province " -- a name which captivated my imagination .
Her tenacity and commitment to the force were exemplary , and her strange beauty had long ago captivated most members of staff .
Elisabeth was no longer interested in these things but was captivated by the Colonel 's enthusiasm for his subjects .
These artists , and the ` progressive rock " bands who came after them , were captivated by the potentiality of the studio as a place for creating new sounds .
Valerie was captivated by him and there seemed nothing her mother could do about it .
Lear was captivated by the extraordinary and extrovert family of parrots .
But she had lifted her skirts a full six inches above the ground as she entered the water , and he was captivated .
This exhilarating performance by the 86-strong company of ` The Wheel of Fortune " inspired by Carl Orff 's ` Carmina Burana " captivated the capacity audiences .
From the start her charm and her missionary addresses captivated her hearers and young people were challenged .
This is the portrait of a woman who captivated Ron Summerfields heart .
The programme captivated , a fantastic mix of early Chinese and European music -- sheng and p'i-p'i twanging happily alongside recorder and viella .

The Temple and royal palace were adorned with gold and ivory from Africa and with cedar from Lebanon ; the beauties and glories of Jerusalem under Solomon have captivated readers of the Bible for almost 3,000 years .
